item.title: Qué significa altercation
item.description: Esta palabra ha aparecido en 343 artículos en NYTimes.com en el último año. ¿Puedes usarla en una frase?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: Word of the Day: altercation
item.description: This word has appeared in 343 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: El CEO de Hyatt Hotels renuncia aludiendo a sus conexiones con Epstein
item.description: Tom Pritzker, también heredero de la fortuna hotelera familiar, dijo que lamentaba “profundamente” su asociación con Epstein y Ghislaine Maxwell.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Davis O’Brien

media:content.media:description: En una carta enviada el lunes a la junta directiva de Hyatt Hotels Corporation, Thomas J. Pritzker dijo que ejerció “un terrible juicio al mantener contacto” con Jeffrey Epstein.

item.title: Trump Has Changed America. Next Up, the World.
item.description: As we lose our alliances and instability spreads, America is headed for more, not fewer, international entanglements.
item.dc:creator: Massimo Calabresi

media:content.media:credit: Photo illustration by Philotheus Nisch for The New York Times

item.title: Alberto Tomba Was an ’80s Icon. The Olympics Have Brought Him Back.
item.description: Nicknamed “Tomba la Bomba,” the Italian skier was a global superstar before he drifted from the limelight. Decades later, the Winter Games have given him a new platform.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz

media:content.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Alberto Tomba in the wine cellar at his home near Bologna, Italy, last month. An Olympic medal winner in the 1980s and ’90s, he is back in the limelight for the Milan-Cortina games.

item.title: Talks on Russia-Ukraine War Enter 2nd Day in Geneva
item.description: The talks in Geneva, Switzerland, were expected to focus on Ukrainian-held territory in the east that Russia wants to control as the price of peace. Kyiv has said that demand is a nonstarter.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut

media:content.media:description: Russia’s top negotiator Vladimir Medinski leaving the Intercontinental hotel in Geneva on Tuesday.

item.title: A Road Trip from Kandahar to Kabul on Highway 1 in Afghanistan
item.description: Life and business are back along a road once defined by war damage. But even with improved security, Afghans are desperate for jobs and development.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Tomás Munita

media:content.media:credit: Tomás Munita for The New York Times

item.title: Corrections: Feb. 18, 2026
item.description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Feb. 18, 2026.

item.title: The Sleepy Market for Japanese Government Bonds Is Now a ‘Battlefield’
item.description: Trading of Japanese government bonds, long considered moribund, is roaring back to life as fears of the country’s debt have sent yields surging.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis

media:content.media:description: The Tokyo Stock Exchange in 1986. In the 1980s and 1990s, yields on Japanese government bonds shifted rapidly alongside fluctuations in Japan’s overall economy.

item.title: Quote of the Day: 3-Time Medalist Tries A Comeback, With a Twist
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, February 18, 2026.

item.title: Manhattan Hospital Ends Medical Treatment for Transgender Youth
item.description: NYU Langone Health cited the “current regulatory environment” in its decision to discontinue its gender medicine program for minors.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Goldstein
item.category: New York University Langone Medical Center

media:content.media:credit: GHI/UCG/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
media:content.media:description: NYU Langone Health in New York City had stopped accepting new patients into its transgender youth medicine program a year ago,

item.title: What Trump’s Latest East Wing Designs Show
item.description: The plans submitted by the White House include more windows, a new garden and an asymmetrical pathway.
item.dc:creator: Junho Lee and Ashley Wu

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Feb. 18, 2026
item.description: Victor Schmitt’s puzzle is picture-perfect.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

item.title: Boneless Wings Are Still Wings, Judge Rules
item.description: A Chicago man filed a lawsuit in 2023 against Buffalo Wild Wings, arguing that it had engaged in false advertising of its boneless wings. A judge said the claim “has no meat on its bones.”
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri

media:content.media:description: A reasonable person would understand that boneless wings are chicken nuggets coated in Buffalo sauce, a judge said on Tuesday.

item.title: House Plans to Vote on Air Safety Bill After Report on Deadly D.C. Crash
item.description: Lawmakers could vote as early as next week on legislation aimed at avoiding another collision like the one that killed 67 people near Reagan National Airport last year.
item.dc:creator: Karoun Demirjian

media:content.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The wreckage of American Airlines Flight 5342 was pulled from the Potomac River last year.

item.title: See Ami Nakai's Triple Axel in the Olympics Figure Skating Short Program
item.description: Japanese figure skaters placed in three of the top four spots after the women’s short program, but only six points separated the medal favorites ahead of the free skate on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Cai, Weiyi Cai, Malika Khurana, Jeré Longman, Joe Ward and Jeremy White

item.title: How a Stray Quote of Jesse Jackson’s Led to a Rupture Between Black and Jewish Voters
item.description: The candidate’s reference to New York as “Hymietown” helped tank his 1984 presidential campaign and eroded a longstanding alliance.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Mahler

item.title: Trump Hails Japan’s First Batch of U.S. Investments
item.description: The deals, totaling $36 billion, were the first step in a $550 billion investment pledge aimed at securing tariff relief and sustaining U.S. relations.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis and Ana Swanson

media:content.media:description: President Trump and Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi in Tokyo in October.

item.title: To One Chicago Resident, Jesse Jackson Was Simply a Friendly Neighbor
item.description: At the Jackson home in Chicago, people paid quiet tributes to a man they said was groundbreaking but also ‘very grounded.’
item.dc:creator: Leigh Giangreco

media:content.media:description: Delores Brown placing flowers in front of Jesse Jackson’s house in Chicago on Tuesday.

item.title: Goldman Sachs to Drop D.E.I. Criteria for Board Members
item.description: The move would be the Wall Street firm’s latest retreat from diversity mandates that its chief executive, David Solomon, had once made a priority.
item.dc:creator: Maureen Farrell

media:content.media:description: David Solomon, the chief executive of Goldman Sachs, had championed an effort to expand the bank’s traditionally white, male-dominated work force.

item.title: Netanyahu Plays Trump and American Jews for Fools — Again
item.description: Netanyahu has gotten Trump to focus on Iran and ignore the destructive things Bibi is doing in Gaza, in the West Bank and inside Israel.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman

item.title: Jesse Jackson’s Death Arrives at a Crucial Moment for Black Political Power
item.description: There are more Black senators than ever before, but a major Supreme Court ruling could reduce Black representation in the House.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti

media:content.media:description: Demonstrators outside the Supreme Court in October, during oral arguments in a case that could significantly weaken the Voting Rights Act.

item.title: ‘Good Progress’ in U.S.-Iran Talks, Iranian Official Says
item.description: Indirect talks between American and Iranian officials in Geneva on Tuesday ended with the two sides agreeing to “a set of guiding principles,” according to the Iranian foreign minister.
item.dc:creator: Monika Cvorak and Jamie Leventhal

item.title: Song of The Week: ‘Bazooka,’ From Memes to Therapy
item.description: Miami XO’s latest release, “Bazooka,” had our critic Jon Caramanica pondering music, memes and grief on the East River ferry.

item.title: Trump Officials Hold High-Stakes Talks in Geneva
item.description: Also, the Epstein emails have rocked several industries. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen

media:content.media:description: Jared Kushner, left, and Steve Witkoff in Switzerland last month.

item.title: What the American Right Wants From Europe
item.description: The tensions in Marco Rubio’s trans-Atlantic vision.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat

media:content.media:credit: Illustration by Shannon Lin/The New York Times

item.title: 4 Dead in Colorado Crash as Strong Winds Kick Up Wildfire Warnings
item.description: High winds were fueling the risk of wildfires across the Southwest and the Plains, and an Oklahoma town faced a mandatory evacuation. Officials said the weather had caused a deadly pileup in Colorado.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk

media:content.media:credit: Christian Murdock/The Gazette, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Emergency workers at the scene of a crash involving 30-plus vehicles, including six semi-trucks, on Interstate 25 south of Pueblo, Colo., on Tuesday.

item.title: Jesse Jackson’s Hometown Remembers Him as a ‘Superstar’
item.description: Mr. Jackson often spoke about Greenville, S.C., in his speeches, returning home several times to fight for change — and for a slice of his favorite banana cream pie.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina and Nick Madigan

media:content.media:credit: Greenville News-USA TODAY NETWORK vis Imagn Images
media:content.media:description: Jesse Jackson at Sterling High School's homecoming game in 1958, in Greenville, S.C.

item.title: Trump Bets on Diplomacy Without Diplomats
item.description: President Trump’s most trusted envoys, Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, are at the center of the Iran and Ukraine negotiations.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Anton Troianovski

media:content.media:credit: Nathan Howard for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner in Israel last October.

item.title: Jesse Jackson Changed Chicago. And It Changed Him.
item.description: Mr. Jackson, who spent much of his life in the city, died at his home there on Tuesday. “He ushered in new politics in Chicago,” one longtime organizer said.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman

media:content.media:description: Jesse Jackson, wearing a hat and with his hands in the air, led a protest over trade union membership in Chicago in 1969.

item.title: Police Arrest Man Who Ran Toward the Capitol With a Loaded Gun
item.description: The 18-year-old arrested was wearing a tactical vest and carrying additional rounds of ammunition, the Capitol Police said. Congress was not in session, and no one was hurt.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil

media:content.media:credit: Elizabeth Frantz for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: The Capitol Police said nobody was hurt and there was no threat to the area after a man with a gun was arrested on Tuesday.

item.title: Triple the pressure, triple the glory.
item.description: Ami Nakai of Japan leads after the short program ahead of a talented field, including the American Alysa Liu, who is third.
item.dc:creator: Victor Mather and Doug Mills

item.title: Judge Blocks Deportation of Columbia Protester Mohsen Mahdawi
item.description: The green card holder from the West Bank had been detained during a citizenship appointment.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ley

media:content.media:credit: Ryan Murphy for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: An immigration judge said the federal government had not met its burden of proving that Mohsen Mahdawi could be removed from the United States.

item.title: Western Civ Can Save Us — Again
item.description: Marco Rubio reminds an audience in Munich of what still unites us.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens

media:content.media:credit: Maria Mavropoulou for The New York Times

item.title: Carnaval de Río: esta es una de las fiestas callejeras más extremas
item.description: El Boi Tolo es una de las celebraciones más emblemáticas de Río de Janeiro y no tiene horario, guion ni ruta. Lo que sí tiene son miles de participantes eufóricos que recorren la ciudad a un ritmo frenético.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova and Dado Galdieri

media:content.media:description: La gente participando en el Boi Tolo el domingo en Río de Janeiro.

item.title: U.S. Indicts Captain of an Oil Tanker the Coast Guard Chased for Weeks
item.description: The charges include falsely flying a Guyanese flag and failing to obey a Coast Guard order to halt the ship for boarding by U.S. forces.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Nehamas, Seamus Hughes and Christiaan Triebert
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:description: The Marinera, an oil tanker previously known as the Bella 1, off the coast of Scotland on Jan. 14, after being seized by the U.S. Coast Guard following a weekslong chase around the Atlantic.

item.title: At an Anti-Valentine’s Day Party, People Commiserate and Celebrate Heartbreak
item.description: On the Monday after Valentine’s Day, guests celebrated not love, but the pain of heartbreak and the cathartic relief of commiseration, at the “Ex Files” party.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta

media:content.media:credit: Ye Fan for The New York Times

item.title: People Celebrate the Lunar New Year Around the World
item.description: People celebrating Lunar New Year welcomed the Year of the Horse with fireworks, festivals and temple visits.
item.dc:creator: Cynthia Silva

item.title: Are you a medical provider who has worked in an ICE detention facility? We want to hear from you.
item.description: We want to get a better picture of what medical care for immigrants in detention is like.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

media:content.media:credit: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: An ICE detention center in Dilley, Texas, in 2019.

item.title: After the Epstein Files Release, Who Has Resigned, Been Fired or Is Being Investigated?
item.description: This list will be updated and includes people who have faced concrete consequences, such as the loss of their position, as a result of their connection to Jeffrey Epstein.
item.dc:creator: Karen Yourish and Lazaro Gamio

item.title: Bad Bunny’s Radical Act Was to Invite Us In
item.description: Bad Bunny invited us to his house for halftime during the Super Bowl. Sasha Weiss, the culture editor at The New York Times Magazine, joins Wesley Morris, the host of “Cannonball,” to discuss how he did it.

item.title: White House Shrugs Off Lutnick’s Epstein Ties
item.description: Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick has acknowledged traveling to Jeffrey Epstein’s island and meeting him on another occasion.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport

media:content.media:credit: Yuri Gripas for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Howard Lutnick, the commerce secretary, is among the Trump administration officials whose names appear in the Epstein files.

item.title: NJ Transit Commuters Grumble as Bridge Work Disrupts Train Rides
item.description: Many people who commute into Manhattan got their first taste of the crowded platforms that are expected to become common over the next month as the Portal Bridge is reworked.
item.dc:creator: Stefanos Chen
item.category: Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers and Trainmen

media:content.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: NJ Transit riders on Tuesday were diverted to the Hoboken station in New Jersey, where there were other transportation options for Manhattan.

item.title: Fania Fénelon, 74; Memoirs Described Auschwitz Singing
item.description: In “Playing for Time,” she recounted how singing in an all-female orchestra while in a concentration camp saved her from death.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Rose Freedman, Last Survivor of Triangle Fire, Dies at 107
item.description: She escaped the Triangle Shirtwaist fire of 1911, in which 146 of her co-workers perished, and dedicated the rest of her life to worker safety.
item.dc:creator: Douglas Martin

item.title: Anna Akhmatova, Leading Soviet Poet, Is Dead
item.description: She was a towering figure in Soviet literature who was once silenced in a Stalinist literary purge.
item.dc:creator: Special to The New York Times

media:content.media:description: Anna Akhmatova in the late 1920s.

item.title: Millvina Dean, Titanic’s Last Survivor, Dies at 97
item.description: She was just 9 weeks old when she was lowered to safety in a mail sack, surviving the worst maritime disaster in history.
item.dc:creator: John F. Burns

media:content.media:description: Millvina Dean in 1994 peering through a porthole that was part of an exhibit called “The Wreck of the Titanic” at the National Maritime Museum.

item.title: Labubu Diplomacy
item.description: China seems to be winning more hearts and minds abroad. Has it gotten better at soft power?
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold

item.title: White House Rejects Democrats’ Latest Proposal as D.H.S. Shutdown Drags On
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times

item.title: Presidents and Faith Leaders Pay Tribute to Jesse Jackson
item.description: His family said in a statement that Mr. Jackson “died peacefully,” but did not give a cause.
